learning_outcomes.description: Evaluate the roles of microorganisms in food spoilage, preservation and fermentation, and their impacts on food quality, safety, and shelf life.
Appraise rapid detection, molecular and genomic methods including real-time PCR, DNA sequencing, and whole genome sequencing for identifying and tracking food-related microorganisms.
Synthesise knowledge of microbial stress responses, spores, and biofilms to assess their significance for food processing and control strategies.
Justify the use of bacteriophages, biocontrol agents and genetically modified microorganisms in food and biotechnological applications.
Interpret experimental data from food microbiology investigations to draw evidence-based conclusions.
Appraise emerging applications in food microbiology and biotechnology, including precision fermentation and alternative protein production

assessments.task_description:
Students will be asked to form groups of 4 (students can choose their group members or the course coordinator can assist them forming groups), and will be allocated ONE rapid microbial technique to investigate. The assignment will be to design a poster that includes: i) the principles; ii) required instrumentation; iii) applications; iv) advantages; and v) disadvantages of the technique. Where applicable, students should aim to have at least 4 key points per section. Referencing all literature resources used for the poster is required. The posters should be A0 in size and clearly and logically set out and should be readable from a distance of 1 to 1.5m. During the face-to-face class the course coordinator will be available to answer questions and guide your group.

All posters will then be presented by the groups at a 'mini-conference' during the tutorial class (location will be advised). Attendance by all members at the Poster session is compulsory. Questions will be asked by the course coordinator and teaching support staff to clarify points and to test understanding.


Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: In hard copy as a poster and to the lecturers during the assigned assessment time. Students MUST be present at their poster during assessment. Non-attendance constitutes grounds for zero mark.
